Btr1b8ez1CV93JSV2xujxA.text: We went on a Monday night and just walked in off the street on the off chance they'd have a table for 8.  They did have a very large table free at the back so we were lucky.  It was a little dark at the back of the restaurant and we had to move a giant vase out of the middle of the table so we could actually see each other.We had a couple of bottles of Malbec which were very good. I had the Hummus with Lamb pieces as a starter which was very good.  All the starters in the group looked good and were generally large portions.  Certainly the bowls of mussels were huge and the mussels themselves were pretty large too!For main course I had the Duck breast which was very good too, although could possibly have been a bit pinker.  Again all the mains looked nice and were larger portions.  The steak looked a little thin and was therefore not medium but apparently tasted good anyway.For dessert I had the waffle with the raspberry coulis and ice cream, which was also very nice.  A number of our group had the cakes from the front of the restaurant and they were apparently very good too.All in all, good service, good food and a good night.

Qx9vyF9yN0vaSD9t9jiKGQ.text: Really lovely restaurant and my new favourite in Islington.Went here for a romantic dinner and we loved everything  the staff were friendly, the food was delicious and although it was busy there was a lovely atmosphere and we never felt rushed.I had the duck followed by the chocolate cheesecake and my partner had the lamb shank followed by gooseberry tart  delicious. the only criticism I have is that we didn't realise that you had to order your veg separately and it would have been a good accompaniment to our mains, but it didn't really matter. Total bill came to around £50 including a bottle of wine (plus 2 free glasses that the manager gave us as we moved tables to accomodate another booking  we didn't mind at all but if someone is going to give me free wine I'm not going to say no!). Make sure you save room for dessert  the selection at the cake buffet by the window at the front is amazing. I'm going back as soon as I can!

DPvAi42k5UghtULnt2WdQQ.text: This is about the fourth time we have visited the Fig and Olive. Normally we go and enjoy the delicious brunch menu. Tonight we treated ourselves to a fantastic evening meal. The staff, as always, were fantastic and welcoming, paying attention to every detail. The atmosphere relaxing and friendly in a modern and chic surrounding. The meal, wine and desserts were Devine. Needless to say, it won't be long before our next visit to the fig and olive. Highly recommended!

NW55JCI4WeWqT5Zg9kkgGw.text: Amazing selection of cakes Really nice simple menu full of real good food that should please everyone. Go :)

YBd3xbFlndMDbi5AS6WcuA.text: Honest food, Good value, Never disappointedthe menu is short but good.Food is good value and so is the wine. The pork is so nice!nice atmosphere.Service not the best but not too bad.it's getting hard to find these sorts of places in London. everything is so overpriced or very mediocre unless you want to spend more than £50 per head .Recommended!

w8cmr3KI5epSQ1fff8Vg9A.text: Having a cake selection in the window is a tried and tested means of drawing in customers. Walking past the brightly lit Fig and Olive I knew that the last piece of White Chocolate Cheesecake was going to be mine. Deciding what I was going to have before that was a lot more difficult. The Fig & Olive suffers from a menu which is quite frankly daunting in size. Between the starters, mains, salads, specials and a brunch selection, it's quite a stress trying to figure out what you actually want to eat. Most people around us we eating breakfasts but I wanted to be a bit more adventurous and so my friend and I opted to share three starters (a plan concocted to make sure that we left plenty of room for cakes later). We choose the Chargrilled Calamari, the Halloumi and Vegetable Stack and the Chorizo in a Parmesan Bowl. All three were great although I'm sure it was not the chef's original intention for the 'Parmesan Bowl' to be quite so chewy. That said, the squid was deliciously seared and the roast vegetables sweet and sticky. The food was also very reasonably priced as the whole meal with coffee's, cakes and wine only costed about £15 each.   The service in this restaurant is great and you can see that the waiters are making a real effort to go that extra mile. When I asked if the slice of Cheesecake was still left my waitress almost sprinted to the front of the building to secure it for me. Despite how busy it was I didn't get the feeling of being rushed or watched over. To me it is the perfect kind of place to go of an afternoon an spend a few hours catching up with friends.

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom

ApcRAboFmL0IpBHY3cAAvw.text: It looks good from outside but once we got inside it was rather unappealing.  There is a retro fablon wall in brown wood grain which is horrible but that is my personal dislike as were the number of mums with screaming pram riders.  Along with the above during our 2 hour long social lunch there were workmen fixing the front door and power planing trhe cupboard doors - hopefully that is a one off.We shared a duck mousse (fine rather than coarse) pate - a large portion with inadequate bread and some green leaves.  Flavour was so soThe fish of the day was N/A and the venison stew was finished so I had lamb steak with fried potatoes and my companion had cardboard in breadcrumbs.  The lamb was excellent as were the potatoes but it lacked a green vegeatable and at over a tenner it should have come with some The cardboard that my friend had was not worth a penny - dry and flavourless chicken with a coating or breadcrumbs and an oily sauce with garlic flavouring does not a chicken schnitzel make.  Absolutley bloody appallingThe desert of strawberry whatever was okay apart from the strawberries which were unripe - our fault for choosing out of season fruit.Don't go thereSPS It is bloody cold in there - even the staff walk around in thick woolly jumpers

UfVm4dGWS-ukYwmyLQm_IA.text: Fig and Olive has such a nice environment. I'm all for a great ambiance, and this place certainly has that! On Islington's Upper Street, which is literally choc-a-bloc full of lovely cafes and restaurants, this one stands out from the rest. I've only had coffee and some of their superb pastries here, but the dinner menu looks fantastic as well. Its reasonably priced too, and is the perfect place for dinner in an elegant and comfortable environment. They can get rather busy on the weekends for lunch, and some of the staff are a tad haughty. Oh well, we won't hold it against them, the environment makes up for any lack of hospitality. There is free Wifi as well, provided though all of Upper Street by Islington's local council.

hd6qJfeIGJ1rV6fZbk4JnA.text: my first brunch in london. just plain sucked. the service is very spotty. You might have to ask 5 times for a glass of water, and they never bring for the entire table. I got the steak with chips, and asked for the steak "rare" and it came close to being burnt and not even tender enough to be cut with a knife (no steak knife for me).not even tasty, just blah...my boyfriend ordered the sunday special beef roast with yorkshire pudding, roasted root veggies and a mega side of blandness. The omlettes looked good, and the big english breakfast looked safe. i have to say that the cappucino/latte was DE-LI-SHOUS :)))Lovely spot with lovely looking attendants, and on a sunny day it's really just the spot to try mediterranean goods (steer away from the meats).

Cgp3CT2G26eW4Na-SrvVjQ.text: The Coffee is nice, cakes ok, service is very good. Deco is nice, prices pretty high (£13.00 for two cappuccinos and 2 cakes) Overall ok but not the best.

Kl7wwGmeNVIoZDZ2HwVk5w.text: Good value pit stop on the main strip in Islington. Attracts a youthful bunch lingering over drinks and watching the world potter down the high street. Stock a surprisingly decent Pinto Grigio. It's a little noisy and the chairs are pretty uncomfortable. But on the whole it's a pretty nice gaff and you're likely to get a pretty decent two course meal for less than £15.

gK5iS_ZOIuywi8WRiY1WLA.text: I came here at the weekend with my Dad, freezing cold and hungry we were enticed inside by the delicious looking cakes in the window and the promise of hot soup.   Not the cheapest option, but we both wanted the pumpkin soup (£4) so it didn't break the bank.   The chic décor is typical of the area , but is understated enough to be warm & welcoming.  There were several  people drinking coffee and making use of the free wifi when we were there.   Although the wooden chairs weren't so comfy that I could imagine myself spending hours using the wifi in there, and I think I'd spend too much money eating all those lovely looking cakes.   They certainly don't come cheap, but I guess you get what you pay for.Friendly and efficient service, our waiter even gave us extra bread for our soup.  It was a good lunch but not somewhere I'd rush back to, especially considering the wealth of choice in the area.

FOqn71-FBTQN-mmtMUEg1Q.text: Venue looks nice, and presentation similar to Ottalenghi (across the rd). I had dinner here (mussaka), and tbh i wasnt that blown awaynevertheless, a decent place for enjoying a cake/coffee while sitting in an armchair.

bxsaV3owUU358Im-ECPLLQ.text: This is a nice place to enjoy a quick bite to eat (i recommend just ordering a starter if your not that hungry) or stay for a longer dinner. The wine is really lovely, the food has been close to perfect every time, especially recommend the fish which is cooked to perfection. the staff can seem a little grumpy at times, but they are efficient and fast. I have to say that it is fairly pricey but cant complain when the general experience is that good.

UC_OyeD19qSOA2MGJI_qNA.text: Great restaurant - delicious food, lovely wine & cocktail menu and friendly service. We went there at the weekend for a quick meal before a show on a Saturday night. They served us promptly and even gave us complimentary wine at the end of the meal! Also v reasonable prices.

MUkyTGvgeMcij6-RslAQWA.text: Sells many fantastic fresh cakes on upper street. The cakes vary from day to day but there's a particularly tasty passion fruit tart which i'd reccomend trying. There is also food available which is also great and a meal for two is likely to cost about £30 which is not too expensive. The decor is pleasant and the seats comfy

ShhwuXN46ICiVelECD72Bg.text: This is one of many plesant little cafes which line Upper Street in Islington. The decor is lovey mixture of classic french with a modern hint.The food is good value, most of the dishes are under £10 and the Sunday lunch is tasty and reasonably priced. This is generally very busy with a mix of people, there are often families eating and shoppers popping in for a quick break. The service is variable- sometimes very attentive other times I have been there and my group's main dishes have been so staggered some had finished before others had started.Overall the food is decent and they have some fantastic desserts on display in the entrance which are very hard to walk past without indulging in!

2QQ3OxIIznOQzuSa4S13yQ.text: This restaurant has alluring decor - white, gleaming, modern, classy. They have the most beautiful cakes and pastries in the window, all of which are delicious and relatively inexpensive.

qcDR-MwkGPfQKtizXi_7Jw.text: Nice cafe/restaurant with nice decor & friendly staff

_HNI0A-035Xe5f6qUAdttw.text: We were off to meet our friends in a nearby pub, so we walked along Upper Street checking out our dining options via the window menus. We saw a lot of interesting menus, but we wanted to see what else we could find... until we saw the Fig & Olive menu.Inside, we found a quaint yet romantic restaurant. The tables and chairs were quite close together, but this London and space is limited. The back is reminiscent of a French solarium with the brick walls and glass ceiling. There is a long heavy wooden table. The top is a lovely whitewashed grey and the legs are a whitewashed mint green. It would be perfect for a nice meal out with a group of 10-12.We ordered the Mix Vegetarian Meze Platter, which contained 3 pieces of pita (a bit skimpy in my opinion, but since this was a starter, I got over it... especially after tasting what was on the plate). It came with hummus, chili ezme salad, an eggplant ratatouille, a small spring salad with balsamic glaze and roasted halloumi cheese. I had no idea what ezme was, but it was like a mediterranean salsa, with the chunky tomatoes, onions and lemon juice (I think). My husband isn't a fan of hummus. I've had him try a few kinds and he just doesn't care for it. Upon trying the hummus at Fig & Olive, I was torn. It was the absolute best hummus I've ever had... I wanted it all to myself, but when you love someone, you share what you love. I told him he should try it, and he really liked it, also. I will go back and get an order of hummus. Possibly just get it to go so no one has to see me eat the entire thing. Chris noted that the halloumi was the best he's tasted.Chris ordered the Roasted Aubergine and Goat Cheese dish. The Eggplant was stuffed with mushroom, fresh pepper, onion & herbs, with rice on the side and topped with caramelised goat cheese. It came on the plate looking quite a bit like fish, which as non fish eaters, we found a bit off putting, but it was really really nice. Again, they did the cheese very well.I opted for the Asparagus and Spinach Risotto. The rice was cooked beautifully, the asparagus was tender, and the spinach and parmesan were nice additions. The rocket and balsamic glaze on top was just the perfect thing. They added just a hint of unique flavour to a great dish.We will definitely be going back. I expect that we'll be back many times.

DQkthNFgkFeBg7I0jiReaA.text: Great value and service. Good Sunday roast and a vast dessert selection. Don't forget to save some room for those cheesecakes! They are simply divine!

gNq-ndCrbhdgLn3EEL-xyg.text: Before I left London I wanted to try as many restaurants as possible, and Fig and Olive was one of them.For appetizer I had the prawns. It was cooked just right, with the perfect texture that is just a slight crunch. The sauce was not overpowering to the prawn's own freshness.For entrée I ordered the cod, which was slightly overcooked. The portion was generous though. I liked the sauce for the cod, but it did not penetrate to the center of the fish, which was slightly bland. My friend ordered the sea bass, and the spinach that came with the dish was delicious and a good compliment to the fish. The skin provided a good counter texture to the fish, which was also cooked just right.For dessert we ordered waffles, and the waffles (recommended by friend) were the reasons we came to Fig and Olive. I had the one with chocolate sauce with ice cream, and it was delicious but not as much as the one my friend ordered - raspberry sauce.I wish I had discovered this place earlier so that I could have had the opportunity to return, but I guess I will just have to wait until I come back for a visit.

0Nt1pN6zY-O8qBpX4zYyQg.text: Decor, service, location, and quaint points for this place. Beyond that, it was pretty meh. The wine list was okay and affordable. OHHHH, and the waffles for dessert were actually fantastic. Unfortunately, despite the charming waiter and adorable ambiance, the food was just not good. Too much gravy does not compensate for too little taste. It's not super expensive so at least I didn't leave filled with disappointment AND rage. Just disappointment. And waffles. The cakes look amazing in the window and, truly, the waitstaff was spectacularly sweet.

iUXO5dt29TJgvYJPIcf4uw.text: The hubby and I wandered into Fig & Olive for lunch and were thrilled were our random find!  We had the grilled calamari as an app.  Yum!  I had the lamb shoulder and the hubby had stuffed chicken breast.  The lamb & mashed potatoes were ammmmazing (although my hubby and I are still arguing over who picked the better meal).  Cool decor, great service and delicious food...can't wait to head back on my next trip to London!

6djrxFT3HoPaEIqr3dMJIQ.text: My partner and I have only visited this place once and will never go back. I can therefore only comment on our experience, but I can say I'm shocked that some people have given an excellent 5 star review. In my opinion the service was the only glimmer of hope for this restaurant, oh and maybe the rosemary and chilli infused olives we shared for starters. Our other starter was cheap, recently defrosted, white baguette with a thin veneer of acrid garlic paste. Not a great start. Drinks were not great either. the water and beer we were served were poured, out of sight, from bottles at the bar. This seems suspiciously odd, when most restaurants pour at the table enabling the diner to see the labels and know the products are fresh. This should have been a sign.We opted for the specials board over the set menu. Roasted Lamb Shank with Mash Potatoes and Aubergines for her and Wild Smoked Haddock in a Hollandaise Sauce with Green Beans and Mash for me. Both dishes were repulsive. First things first, the Lamb didn't taste like Lamb, the sauce was a funny artificial colour and was strangely reminiscent of Heinz BBQ sauce. I ate a lot of this, too much to complain convincingly about afterwards, not so the Haddock. With it's top hat of leathery skin and texture like an old plimsole, not even the sulphurous yellow hollandaise sauce could rescue it. What a shame, and it wasn't cheap. £11 may not buy much in restaurants around Angel, but it buys a packet of Birds Eye Fish Fingers, and I'd reluctantly prefer the latter any day of the week. We complained because it was obvious from the full plates we were unhappy. This was met with shock, and thankfully a reduction in the price of the bill. We didn't pay for the Haddock, even though the waiter insisted it was freshly caught 24 hours ago. Pollocks.We didn't have desserts, for obvious reasons, but they looked appetising. A coffee and a cake might have been a wiser decision.

kvCv1utYzvQghgKuFwBXZw.text: Nice Cafe. Excellent Waffles, good selection of cake & antipasti. Can highly recommend It.

gYt8fp6XMwW89rZqWD9d4g.text: We popped in here after our Sunday Roast just around the corner.  We felt like something sweet to round off the meal and the display cheesecakes attracted us in.I got a creme brulee cheesecake and my partner got a lime and cookie cheesecake.  They were nice and hit the spot, but a little on the expensive side.

cziD69rYuRq-hB1NJWqGXQ.text: All mouth and no trousers!Islington is obviously marvelous with all it's huge array of tastefull middle class liberal consumerism but appearances and aesthetics are not always enough. Given the plethora of places to swallow coffee and cake you need to keep at the top of your and your neighbours game. So when we strolled into the doppleganger interior of Fig and Olive and paid 13 quid for two coffees and a couple of cake slices you want the best. The very best. Weak luke warm coffee, an over sweet lemon meringue pie and a slightly too dry huge chocolate brownie. Server good, food bad.

JV1MqJtJI2q2YP1OVPzzQQ.text: I went there for a late night dinner on a Thursday evening.  I had the roasted aubergine and goat cheese dish - super tasty! My friend had the veggie mousakka and also really liked it. The service is pretty quick and waiters are friendly. Very cool vibe. Nice location. Awesome that they are open pretty late for dinner - everything was closed when we looking for food and I am glad we ran into this place! Would definitely go back.

OUZFnQGmu3MmLbOUKkNKOg.text: As an area Islington seems to have the whole young professional family down. A pleasant consequence of which is a lot of nice cafes including Fig & Olive. The cafe has a very comfortable feel about it and is a wonderful place for Sunday morning coffee, or a quick coffee and a pastry. The cakes are wonderful, as are the staff. A charming cafe to take a shopping break in.

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom

RF7izZl1CzUn0ZwFtX1Vwg.text: I got temporary amnesia from how good the food is here. After I left I totally forgot that I had eaten here. Do they roofie the food so you'll come back?Two words that will change your life... Mashed. Potatoes. Boy howdy, do Fig and Olive know how to mash a potato? And I didn't even order it, I just couldn't keep my fork out of someone else's plate. I walk by all the time and their selection of insanely amazing cakes always draws my eye. So finally I dragged Laura N. in for dinner and since we both weren't drinking, we decided to eat everything. Their stuffed aubergine was cheesy and delicious, but it was the baked cod with mash that made me see nirvana. The hollandaisey style sauce was so creamy and satisfying it was an orgasm on a plate. Only low point was that they forgot my fries and by the time they arrived, I was Joey-fat-pants full.. but they never charged for them, so that is nice service. No room for cake, in the immortal words of Arnie... I'll be back. P.s I forgot to mention the decor is so cool and chilled out, but again, food amnesia, I only saw mash.

NNahoCaElhZYAPqRQWbTTA.text: What an amazing restaurant. They have fantastic desert and salad buffet in front of the restaurant and they taste how they looked. On my last visit I had seared scallops with Apple pure, it was nice and juicy and followed by slowed cooked lamb shoulder with mashed potato. It was full of taste and flavored. Service was polite and the decoration was very pretty. For the price, you'd be hard pushed to get a better meal in islington. I will go back soon. Highly recommended.

Pw-Ll5HCpKz4FvTOycYcGQ.text: Having heard a great review from a friend about this restaurant, decided to go and eat as a date night event.  All I can say is that the food was amazing.  I'm a seafood addict, and the salmon was excellent!  The display of desserts in the front window really are as good as they look!  I had the vanilla cheesecake and it was great.  Light for a cheesecake, but that is exactly what I wanted after filling up on the great grub.  Went on a Friday with no reservations and were able to be squeezed in at a somewhat early hour for around two hours.  Definitely make reservations for anything after 19:00 on the weekends and if you want to relax and take time with your meal.There were also the more pricey dishes on the menu, but one can eat at a relevantly decent price if wanting to.

d6jKH3Q6L8uiIXrVT3eQBA.text: Fig & Olive (a haiku)Hungry, I came in -I ordered perhaps wrongly.I left, unsatiated.

C6kfCqaisJ9RJZyXC6wLrQ.text: i ordered the duck breast and it was cooked perfectly at medium, with a flavorful mushroom sauce reduction and potatoes. we went here with a large group of 14 and ordered plenty of good red wine. i'd return, but don't come here extremely hungry as the portions are modest.

jX6kBubHBo5Hw85rhNjyVA.text: I've wanted to eat here ever since the soft glow of its window first beckoned me with its resplendent display of luscious cakes caught my eye.  Yes, I know it's a rip-off of Ottolenghi across the street, but the designers of Fig & Oliver did an equally good job of making the little place look oh-so-enticing.  And indeed, once inside, the atmosphere is alluring and candlelit; every detail, right down to the service and demeanor of the wait staff, is soothing.My friends and I popped in here late Friday evening for a bottle of wine and a few nibbles.  It was a cold night, so we all ended up ordering the soup of the day - a mellow orange sweet potato served in a sculptural white bowel.  It was a nice thick soup with gentle seasoning - rich and succulent.  We also ordered the hummus with lamb and the tower of grilled vegetables and halloumi.  The hummus was typical, but we were a little divided about the success of the vegetable dish.  The vegetables were grilled zucchini and aubergine, covered in a strange and smoky red sauce that I though complimented the halloumi, but was the absolute wrong pairing for the aubergine - another friend, however, quite liked it.The best part about this place is that it's open late - they take last food orders at 11:30.  Now, for someone who's habitually trying to find dinner after 10pm, and refuses to do kebab shops, this is a heavenly godsend.  I mean, wine, freshly prepared food, and upscale service in a calm and aesthetically charming establishment well after 11?  All I have to say is "thank you."

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom. Inside Fig & Olive
Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom. Glowing Windows

ucgUyPOIXLSvLhWEVLgXtw.text: The caramel profiterole cheesecake is INTENSE. and i'm a sugar freak! £3 take away is pretty expensive but to be fair the ingredients are probably quite expensive!

IA8lBLozi-ocXXKlZ_3gPA.text: While I think that weekend dining in London is legally reserved for the famed Sunday Roast, there is an underground brunch movement bubbling to the surface. You have to search in unexpected places, but seek and you shall find, as we did at Fig & Olive.Frankly, neither figs nor olives really whet my brunch appetite, but upon first glance at the neighboring ginormous plates of sausage, hash browns, eggs and toast, I knew I would be in for something delicious. Coffee? Fantastic. Definitely a good start. When my plate of food arrived, I was presented with a veritable bouquet of wheat toast, fluffy scrambled eggs, and blossom of pink smoked salmon in the center.  At that point, all conversation devolved into a cacophony of forks to plates and mmms and ahhhs. Maybe weekend brunch isn't shining in full glory as it does in the states, but no one bothered telling Fig & Olive. Regardless, a line of patrons out the door proved that brunch culture can (and should) be alive and well in London. Bring on the brunch!

BrWqKnnWTsYeeF_Vl6i9uw.text: Being a South London gal, I haven't ventured and explored the Islington/Angel area too extensively of late so when a friend suggested meeting at the Fig and Olive, I was pleasantly surprised at how cool and kitsch it has become. Located at the end of Upper Street, this wonderful restaurant ticks all the right boxes for a Saturday morning meet.It was super busy but I managed to secure a table pretty quickly - on looking at the menu, it is somewhat overwhelming with a combination of good British breakfast choices in addition to some more Mediterranean type dishes. I actually thought it was just a cafe so ate breakfast beforehand, but I suddenly found myself being eyed up by the 2 big (huge) and delicious looking breakfasts served to the gents next to us. Instead I safely opted for a filter coffee (note to self; never eat breakfast before coming here or cut your losses and prepare for a 'fat' day). My friend had the salmon and scrambled eggs which she can vouch was rather yummy, healthy and filling. My only 'complaint' was that after our drinks and food, we were asked to move tables to accommodate some people who had been waiting twenty minutes to be seated. This seemed a little odd considering we wanted to order a further round of coffees and if I had been in a worse mood, I may have been more annoyed but hey, the coffee was excellent, food great and the atmosphere buzzy. On our way out, I couldn't help but notice the gorgeous and decadent looking cakes and desserts on display - it was so busy I didn't stop to sample but definitely maybe next time......

-87PFwCLdDq6686FheeJcg.text: Our first meal in London after finding our way to our Airbnb was the Fig & Olive, because it had the least pretentious sounding menu of anywhere we passed. For being not very busy it was a little slow getting served, and seemed a little pricey (little did we know how pricey things were going to be generally).I don't know if there was an intended theme or type of cuisine because while some things were basically "Mediterranean" others were just ... whatever(?) standards. In any case, for a lunch, we thought it was a decent place to go.

G4DO4xVBSldlu43uyxy4gw.text: One of our first restaurant here in London. Went in on a cold December night. Loved the atmosphere. Ordered the Portobello Mushrooms for starters. They were juicy and yum. The best part of the meal was the VegatableCroustillant(V) which came in a pastry that was crunchy yet not flaky. Absolutely delicious. Also had their mushroom gratin which was good.Also tasted their Banoffee pie along with a strawberry cheescake.Would definitely go back for their deserts!

PKCujGYzcPoZ7hh9K6x1Xg.text: I do not recommend eating here. The cost of the food is way too steep for the poor quality. I had a burger and my boyfriend the duck. The meat was very over cooked (even though I asked for medium-rare it was well done) and flavourless. The atmosphere looked like it would be nice with the natural light streaming through the front windows but the staff hovered before we ordered and then ignored us until we pointed out that we were finished. We walked away dissatisfied and are suffering the stomach annoyance from a terrible meal. One nice thing was they didn't charge us for the over cooked burger. I will never eat here again.

3xONIiZjSHl2IAI1WToM4g.text: What a cute place!I was in the area needing a quick coffee fix and thought I'd drop in to see what they had to offer a girl like me.The staff were exceedingly friendly, smiley and should've been surrounded by singing Disney birds.The decor inside made me feel like i was in rome or something (and that my dears is a great thing)However, the weather was rather nice so we chose to sit outside, which was the right decision despite having to fight a local spider on our table.With spider man evacuated, I ordered a mocha with cream and wasn't disappointed.It was chocolatey, milky and gave me the coffee kick I needed. Not to mention it was only £2.50! Although, I must say I did wait about 10minutes for the coffee but I won't complain too much about that because it was well made ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom. So much cream yay!

uzxz2wpgVETDl9JGbNjvRQ.text: I've been to Fig & Olive in the past and had mixed reviews in terms of the food.  One thing for sure, they used to do this amazing roast lamb dish which was really yummy.  Didn't see it on the week menu but hopefully still available on a Sunday.  I stopped going here a few years ago due to cleanliness issues.  They once gave me a glass and it had a big spider in it complete with spider webs.   They were very apologetic but once seen cannot be unseen!  I particularly hate spiders.  There was also an issue with flies and wasps pitching on the desserts in the window which were not covered.But I'm happy to report that all is changed.  The desserts are now in a glass cabinet, the decor seems to be improved it looks lovely and the cleanliness issues seemed to be sorted out.  I was happy to order dessert, lemon meringue pie in fact, it was quite nice.  Overall pretty impressed.  I can now come back to dining at the Fig & Olive.

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom. Strawberry Tart
Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom. Lemon Meringue Pie
Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom

jWC5nmDLmcgz2euia07suw.text: I reallllllllllllly liked this place!Happened to come across it by accident in need of some caffeine.Changed my mind and had a mocha with cream! Lol a strong caffeine fix could wait!The staff were super friendly and welcoming and the decor was rather beautiful in my opinion.. Modern and bright with just enough colours to seduce you!!Their mocha with cream was the creamiest mocha I've ever had and I loved it!!!! It was partially sweetened so they didn't put sugar on the table .... Now I think about it I would've liked to make that choice for my bloody self! No one controls my sugar intake but me!!! On a less volatile note, we sat outside as it was a lovely day and people watching is a great activity lol. It took them 10 minutes to make our drinks but I won't complain as it tasted great! Price wise ... Exceptionally resonable...  £2.50 I would go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom

HD0lR3l6shqNKGzYnGmmag.text: Went here for thanksgiving dinner with a couple friends and family. They advertised a 20% off food discount on Opentable, which we booked on, but when we requested to redeem it, the manager told us that it didn't go through and to try again. Fair enough, so we tried again, this time making sure that the offer went through. However, she refused to honour it, and even told us to "look at the computer and see that it didn't go through." Then she berated us for trying again, saying that she "has to pay 2 pounds each time she gets a booking through that app". Just felt the customer service was pretty disappointing. The thing is, the food was fine. Mains were good portion wise, I got a steak. Small portions with the apps and quite pricey overall. Was just kind of a dampener on a nice Thanksgiving dinner.

mAn1kJ08o4ZwsAzGOefiHw.text: We walked past Fig & Olive and the luscious looking salads and cakes on display caught my eye. First we sat outside because it was nice and sunny but then asked for a table inside because the street is a bit too busy and loud. The long table in the back is beautiful but the rest of the restaurant is not especially classy.I wanted a light lunch so I went for the Fig & Olive Salad, hoping that this signature dish would give me the best impression of the restaurant. Technically the salad was lovely but sadly it was cmopletely oversalted. I was with company so I didn't send it back to the kitchen but really I should have. I guess this can happen so I'm not writing this place off for good. I might give them another chance some time.

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom. The Fig & Olive Salad and Chicken Quesadilla

Nc5C9xN3zZxDOqq5EYjjmA.text: The Fig and Olive was recommended to me by my partner as he had been there a couple of years ago. The decor was nice with a conservatory looking part at the back of the restaurant. We were sat at the very front of the shop by the door. The waiters were very friendly and took our order within about 5 minutes. The menu had a variety of different foods to suit different times of the day. I went for a 'light lunch' and ordered the chicken quesadilla and halloumi. The prices were very reasonable for Upper Street at approximately £6.50-8.50 for a meal.I was a bit disappointed when my partners food came out first and it was about 5 minutes before I received my food - they even forgot the halloumi! Aside from the slight mishap, the food was yummy! I can confidently say this restaurant is good for buggies as the waiter was very happy to rearrange some sofas in order to get the baby in!Despite the slight hiccup with the halloumi, I would recommend The Fig and Olive for a light and a nice atmosphere.

XhGDLAKlh2drvsoLmli-kw.text: Had a nice evening meal here yesterday. The cuisine is Greek/Mediterranean with a good range for both veggies and meat lovers. I can recommend the veggie moussaka and the aubergine with goats cheese. The staff we very happy and helpful. They were very apologetic when theh served my Mum her moussaka as it  was on the small side. When they had cooked a new batch they presented her with a second plate of moussaka and salad!! The desserts were ok, but not very fresh tasting, and my red velvet cake a little dry at the edges. The lemon tart was pretty tasty though!

RT3ArbkB-JzTMjDsOfAokg.text: Maybe my expectations were too high - a friend told me this was her favorite restaurant in London. I was underwhelmed. The menu was a mishmash if different cuisines. I had the moussaka and my dining companion had the coq au vin. We shared three of the starters, all deep fried. Nothing was bad but nothing particularly stood out either. Portion sizes were quite large, especially the chicken. I might come back to try the desserts but not sure if it will be soon though.

pbCRrSwDM1AxoYYSdOCpMg.text: Something at Fig + Olive doesn't quite do it for me but it is hard for me to explain just what that is.The food here is certainly good. Hummus started its redemption with me at this restaurant. On my recent visit i enjoyed the Pumpkin, butternut squash + manchego cheese soup. The goats cheese + aubergine risotto is a trusty main course. The desserts look. A-MAZE-ZING as you arrive and leave, but I never have room to test them on my not particularly sweet tooth.I keep thinking that they don't have much choice. Its true that I don't eat much meat, but they have like half a dozen vegetarian options. I think that I have this impression means that not many of the choices particularly appeal to me.There was an order mix up on my last visit with some confusion over the soup of the day. Turns out there were two different soups of the day and this ended with us getting both...and another starter we had ordered. But we got the extra accidental starter for free so that really removes the reason to complain.I think perhaps it is just a little classy for me. It is quite posh and a little more expensive than my usual meals. There is nothing wrong with the food but none of the main courses get my mouth watering and make me excited to order. It is all quite tightly packed together in a small space (the chairs and tables, not the food).But I think the problem may be more mine than the restaurant. My rating feels a little harsh but I gots to go with my gut.

bcwGDYKHgNRY-cwKeIkxWg.text: I decided to treat myself to a Friday afternoon off, and what better way to spend it than with a stroll up Upper Street. As I hadn't been to the area for ages I was keen to try a genuine Islington institution in favour of the many chains outlets.I just love afternoon tea and was drawn in by the tempting display of cakes, even though they all look a bit on the heavy side. I opted for a brulee cheesecake which was served lovingly decorated. Sadly, this was just too sugary even for my sweet tooth.

photos.caption: Photo of Fig & Olive - London, United Kingdom

YQ1WYMDlfJCqTPoBzrqUaA.text: Tried some very flavourful crab cakes and duck salad for starters here. Followed it with 'Falafel the Fig and Olive Way', which is essentially a few pieces of falafel in a yummy tomato-vegetable concoction. Falafel itself was nice and crispy, reasonable by UK standards. For dessert we had ice cream on a hot waffle with a delicious raspberry coulis. They also have an impressive display of other desserts - all sorts of luxurious cakes, Sicilian cannoli, and so on.

NA30shHAGagjai7YbZ-y2w.text: I go here as often as I can and have never had an unsatisfactory meal. I particularly recommend their minute steak and also the risotto. Both are yummy. Not a fan of the cannoli or how loud it can get, but service is efficient and pleasant and I love to have Sunday brunch there!

LO5peInzaCwigJIp-XoaFw.text: Great place for a steak if you are out late.   Try the Bodega Norton Malbec.  Great value for the money, a really excellent wine.   The service was also top notch and friendly.

8b6_28-xBNMWmItmA0IDcg.text: After yet another lovely lunch here, thought it was well overdue to review! Upper street is crawling with restaurants, bakeries and cafes these days, but Fig and Olive is a real standout for it's delicious food, reasonable prices and adorable atmosphere.  Breakfast/brunch here is great value, with meals between £6-13.  I've had the veggie full breakfast (all great minus one kind of dodgy vegetarian sausage), the Halloumi Salad, and most recently, the pancakes with bacon - all so yum!  Clean, bright space, with friendly staff and strong coffee make for a great place to spend a lazy Sunday morning/afternoon.This will continue to be a top choice for me!

5DUajhxqIpatrPKN17aLrA.text: Dropped in here for breakfast over the weekend....I couldn't make up my mind between the nicoise salad or the asparagus risotto.... so, since it was fa-reezing and SNOWING, I took a chance on the risotto and I'm glad I did. It was warm, creamy and nicely seasoned, with a lot of great textures.  Yum. It's definitely an easy weekend brunch and lunch spot.

SKOsuIkyQ0c5njji1hdnvA.text: Something great about this place! Feels very sophisticated without the pretentious price tag. The food is delicious and interesting and service very good. Every time I've taken people here they've been super impressed. Varid choice of mains and specials so will definitely be coming back again soon!

-Wg01SgA1XglwllxNCrcgw.text: Fig & Olive is pretty much my go-to local place whenever I have visitors, and it never disappoints. Most recently, took a friend visiting from the US. We started (as I always do) with the deep fried camembert, and also had the hummous, which were both great. For mains, I tried the lamb steak, and the friend had the shin of pork, which were delicious. I've always been happy with the service, and find that the prices are really reasonable for what you get (considering the neighbourhood). I'll undoubtedly be back again soon.
